questions.text: Deposition of which of the following is responsible for band-shaped keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Band-shaped keratopathy is caused by pathological calcium deposition on the cornea in the form of a band.

On exam, there is a white band-like formation of calcium across the corneal surface with irregular borders and a peripheral clearing of cornea between the calcium deposits and the limbus. The calcium deposition is typically found beneath the epithelial layer within Bowman’s layer but may extend into the anterior stroma.

Once the visual axis starts to get involved, there will be progressive loss of vision. Recurrence is common unless the predisposing cause is identified and treated.

Local causes such as chronic ocular irritation or inflammatory conditions and systemic diseases that elevate serum calcium levels are the main causes for band-shaped keratopathy. It can rarely have hereditary causes as well.

Image given below shows band-shaped keratopathy.

questions.text: A patient was with the given finding has been having painless and slowly progressive vision loss for the past 10 years. Which of the following diseases is not associated with the given condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario and ocular finding depicted here, it is suggestive of band-shaped keratopathy, and systemic lupus erythematosus is not associated with this condition. 

Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK) is due to calcium deposition, primarily in the form of hydroxyapatite, in the epithelial basement membrane, Bowman's layer, and the anterior stroma. Initially, these deposits are grey but may become chalky-white as the degeneration progresses.

lt typically presents as a band-shaped opacity in the interpalpebral zone with a clear interval between the ends of the band and the limbus. The condition begins at the periphery and gradually progresses towards the centre. The surface of this opaque band is stippled due to holes in the calcium plaques in the area of nerve canals of Bowman's membrane.

Causes of band-shaped keratopathy include local causes such as chronic ocular irritation or inflammatory conditions and systemic diseases that elevate serum calcium levels:

Local causes Systemic diseases
  • Chronic anterior uveitis (especially in Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis)
  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Superficial keratitis
  • Phthisis bulbi
  • End-stage glaucoma
  • Silicone oil left in the aphakic eye
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Paget disease
  • Chronic renal failure
 

Treatment:

  • Medical management- Chelation using topical ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) 1.5–3.0% 
  • Surgical management- Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) using excimer laser or manual superficial keratectomy

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman was brought by her son, during a cataract outreach camp.  She gives a history of trauma to her left eye, one year back and a complete loss of vision in that eye since then. Her image is given below. Which of the following statement is true about her condition?

choices.text: Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in this lady.
The given lesion is an adherent leucoma.
It is due to scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial stroma.
Excimer laser phototherapeutic keratectomy is the current treatment of choice.

questions.solution:
The above image shows a dense white opacity, which results from the scarring of more than half of the stroma,  characteristic of leucoma.

Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities, who have lost their vision or who do not expect to recover it. It improves cosmetic appearance by altering the white colour of the opacity and blending it to normal eye colour.

Depending on the density, corneal opacities are graded as nebula, macula and leucoma. 

  • Nebular corneal opacity (fog or mist):
    • Hard-to-see corneal scar, due to superficial scars involving Bowman's layer and superficial stroma.
    • Slit-lamp detection is required.
    • A thin, diffuse nebula covering the pupillary area interferes more with vision than the localised leucoma away from the pupillary area. Nebula produces more discomfort due to blurred image (irregular astigmatism).
  • Macular corneal opacity:
    • Semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination.
    • Due to scarring involving about half the corneal stroma.
  • Leucomatous corneal opacity (leucoma simplex):
    • White scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye.
    • Due to scarring of more than half of the stroma 
  • Adherent leucoma:
    • It results when healing occurs after perforation of the cornea with incarceration of iris

Secondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyaline degeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration.

Treatment:

  • Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities.
  • Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas
  • Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial (nebular) corneal opacities.

Related Pearl: Corneal Opacities

Corneal opacity is formed when Bowman's layer (+/- deeper layer) is damaged.

Nebular opacity

  • Faint white
  • Only Bowman's layer is involved
  • Causes more visual handicap than macular opacity due to the scattering of light

Macular opacity

  • White in color
  • Bowman's layer + Half of stromal thickness involved

Leucoma

  • White and opaque
  • BM + half or more than half stromal thickness involved

Image: Leucomatous corneal opacity

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with bilateral corneal opacities in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Keratoglobus is least likely to be associated with bilateral corneal opacities in a neonate. Here, the cornea is clear. 

Keratoglobus is a rare noninflammatory, familial disorder marked by generalised thinning and globular protrusion of the cornea. It can be congenital or acquired. The thinning is usually greatest at corneal periphery or midperiphery. It can cause refractive errors, otherwise, cornea is clear, normal angle of anterior chamber, normal intraocular pressure with no optic disc cupping.

Intrastromal ring segments and cross-linking can be used for management.

Other options: 

Option B: Birth injuries resulting in Descemet's membrane tears can also cause corneal opacities.

Option C: Peter's anomaly, also known as iridocorneal adhesions or keratolenticular adhesions, is a posterior corneal defect with an overlying stromal opacity.

Option D: Sclerocornea is a congenital disorder in which the cornea is opaque and resembles the sclera, making the limbus indistinct. The central cornea is clearer than the periphery.

Related Pearl: Causes of congenital opacities of the cornea

Causes of congenital opacities of the cornea (STUMPED)

S - Sclerocornea

T - Tears in the Descemet membrane secondary to birth trauma or congenital glaucoma

U - Ulcer

M - Mucopolysaccharidosis

P - Peters anomaly

E - Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy

D - Dermoid

questions.text: What causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Neurotrophic keratopathy is caused by trigeminal nerve palsy.

Lesions of the fifth cranial nerve from the trigeminal nucleus to the cornea may lead to abnormalities of the normal corneal sensation and trophic stimulation.

Causes:

  • Varicella-zoster (most common cause)
  • Herpes simplex keratitis
  • Trauma
  • Irradiation to the eye
  • Aneurysm/stroke
  • Multiple sclerosis

Mackie characterized three stages of neurotrophic keratitis.

  • Stage I is characterized by an irregular corneal surface, which later develops into an easily recognized punctate keratitis.
  • Stage II is characterized by a frank epithelial defect, which is typically associated with mild anterior stromal oedema and inflammation.
  • Stage III involves stromal melting and occasionally perforation.

questions.text: Paralysis of which of the following nerves is responsible for exposure keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve.  

It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos) resulting in drying of the cornea (despite normal tear production).

Causes:

  • Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy
  • Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism
  • Mechanical such as lid scarring
  • Proptosis

Note: Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partial or complete loss of sensation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
Erythromycin is least likely associated with cornea verticillata/vortex keratopathy, a whorl-like opacity in corneal epithelium, as shown in the image above. 

Vortex keratopathy occurs due to corneal deposits in the basal epithelium. They are almost always bilateral and are readily recognisable by their distinct appearance as fine, golden-brown or grey opacities that branch out from a central whorl, usually across the inferior cornea. Opacity due to drugs is reversible upon stopping the drug.

Causes:

  • Amiodarone (most common) (Option A)
  • Tamoxifen (Option C)
  • Indomethacin
  • Chloroquine (Option D)
  • Chlorpromazine (rarely)
  • Fabry’s disease

questions.text:
A 30-year-old albino woman presents with a characteristic finding as shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the suspected condition?
  1. It is due to the deposition of copper in the Descemet's membrane
  2. It requires screening for underlying lipid disorder
  3. It is seen in patients with the neurological form of Wilson’s disease
  4. If seen unilaterally it is suggestive of ipsilateral carotid stenosis
  5. It is also called limbus sign
questions.solution:
A 30-year-old individual with corneal changes, as shown above, known as gerontoxon or arcus lipoides, may require screening for underlying lipid disorder.

Arcus senilis (AS), also known as gerontoxon, arcus lipoides or arcus cornealis, is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity, typically benign, occurring bilaterally and prevalent among the elderly.

However, when observed in individuals under 50, termed arcus juvenilis, it may indicate underlying lipid disorder and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, warranting lipid profile screening. Unilateral cases of arcus senilis may indicate contralateral carotid artery stenosis due to decreased ophthalmic blood flow on the ipsilateral side, resulting in protection from forming arcus in the ipsilateral eye.

The condition results from the leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma, initiating deposition at the superior and inferior cornea. Over time, the ring progresses circumferentially, sparing a clear corneal zone adjacent to the limbus called the interval of Vogt.

The following opacities and rings can resemble arcus senilis:

  • Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring: A dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in Descemet's membrane, classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. 
  • Limbus sign: Caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a "milky precipitate" at the corneal limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population.
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon: A greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

The image below depicts the Kayser–Fleischer ring and anterior capsule of the crystalline lens (Sunflower cataract) seen in Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A young male labourer presents to the casualty with severe bilateral eye pain that woke him from sleep. He reports welding the previous afternoon without a face shield and symptoms of photophobia, blurry vision, tearing, and worsening pain in bright light. Examination reveals mild conjunctival injection and diffuse punctate epithelial erosions on the cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The described corneal findings, with his classic history of welding less than 12 hours prior to presentation, are suggestive of photophthalmia. 

Photophthalmia is produced due to exposure to short-wavelength ultraviolet (UV-B) rays. The cornea absorbs the majority of UV light (especially 311 to 290 nm). It results in desquamation of the epi­thelium leading to multiple painful corneal erosions. Causes of of UV keratitis:

Artificial causes  Natural causes
  • Arc welding
  • Flash from short-circuits,
  • Damaged metal halide lamps
  • Tanning beds
  • UV germicidal lamps.
  • Exposure to strong solar radiation at high altitudes especially on snow-covered terrain (snow blindness) 
  • Prolonged viewing of a solar eclipse without proper eye protection. 

The symptoms appear characteristically after a latent period of 4- 5 hours of exposure to ultraviolet light. There is intense burning pain, foreign body sensation, and watering of the eyes. There may be associated marked photophobia and blepharospasm. On slit-lamp examination, corneal epithelium shows a breach in continuity and takes up fluorescein stain. 

Management comprises cold compresses, lubricant eye drops and bandaging eyes for 24 hours with antibiotic eye ointment and cycloplegic. Avoid local surface topical anaesthesia. Crooke’s glass is a prophylactic aid consisting of a spectacle lens combined with metallic oxides to absorb ultraviolet or infrared rays and should be used by those who are prone to exposure.

Note: Photoretinitis and macular burns are often a result of infrared radiation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a method for long-term preservation of cornea?
questions.solution:
Cryopreservation is used for long-term preservation of cornea, up to 1 year.

Related Pearl: Corneal Preservation

Corneal preservation – They can be transplanted immediately or preserved in an eye bank by various preservation techniques for varying intervals.

  • Short-term preservation
    • In a moist chamber or McCarey–Kaufman medium (MK medium)
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C
    • Cornea to be used within 48 to 72 hours (maximum 96 hours)
  • Intermediate– term preservation
    • In medium containing chondroitin sulfate
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C for 7 to 14 days
    • Or maintained at 37°C by organ culture methods
    • Using modified Eagle's medium extends this to 30 days
  • Long-term preservation
    • By cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or in glycerol
    • Is up to 1 year
    • Loss of transparency of the tissue is a disadvantage.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection following corneal transplantation in India?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of infectious keratitis after corneal transplantation in developing countries.

Pneumococcus spp. and Staphylococcus aureus have been found to be the most common causes of post-corneal transplant infections in developed countries.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is the gold standard for assessing corneal thickness?
questions.solution:
The gold standard technique for assessing corneal thickness is ultrasound pachymetry, which uses a corneal pachymeter.

Measurement of the corneal thickness (pachymetry) indirectly reflects endothelial function. The average central corneal thickness is around 0.5 mm, which gradually increases toward the periphery to around 0.7 mm. Normally, as a diurnal variation, corneas tend to be slightly thicker just after a person awakes in the morning.

Other options: 

Option A: Confocal microscopy is an imaging technique that allows in vivo examination of corneal structures at high magnification and resolution. It is used to assess corneal nerve morphology and corneal endothelium.

Option B: Keratometry measures the anterior corneal curvature and is traditionally performed with a manual keratometer, also known as an ophthalmometer.

Option D: Corneal topography is used to assess the anterior corneal surface, its shape and thickness. 

The image below shows a corneal pachymeter.

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: Your aunt recently shared that it is becoming cumbersome for her to frequently change her glasses. You suggested a referral and the rapid change in power was diagnosed to be due to keratoconus. The following image shows the results of one of the investigations done on her. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.solution:
The investigation shown in the image is corneal topography, and it is used for conditions like keratoconus, as seen in this clinical scenario.

Corneal topography captures the shape of the cornea by projecting concentric rings of light onto its anterior surface, forming a Placido disc pattern. the reflected light is analyzed with specialised software to create a detailed map of the corneal curvature. 

Uses:

  • Detection of corneal ectasia, mainly keratoconus
  • To measure corneal thickness
  • Prior to refractive surgery
  • Sometimes prior to contact lens fitting

The image shows a Placido or Keratoscopic disc which is used for corneal surface assessment. 

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl with high myopia was referred by the optometrist for further evaluation. She has a history of recurrent allergic conjunctivitis and persistent eye rubbing. An image is given below. Which of the following statements are true about the given condition?
  1. It is usually associated with regular astigmatism
  2. Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool
  3. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice
  4. Vogt's striae and Rizzuti sign are both findings 
  5. The area of protrusion is mostly inferotemporal
questions.solution:
Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder.  It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigid contact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenital amaurosis, and connective tissue disease.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection. 

Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is now generally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical or non-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It is the definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in advanced keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Vision correction with spectacles with spherical/toric soft contact lenses is suboptimal and only applicable to the early stages of keratoconus, not in the advanced stages.

Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory, bilateral corneal ectasia characterized by cone-like steepening due to irregular stromal thinning. This leads to a conical corneal protrusion, significant vision loss, myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

The available options for the management of keratoconus are highly dependent on the stage of the disease and its progression. If the disease is stabilized (no progression), the emphasis is given to correcting the vision. If the disease is progressing, the emphasis is on slowing (arresting) the progression.

Treatment options in moderate-to-advanced keratoconus:

  • Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses and vaulting scleral lenses are the mainstays of vision treatment for moderate to advanced KCN. Their main advantage is the creation of a tear pool between the lens and the cornea, which naturally neutralizes the ocular aberrations associated with keratoconus. (Option B and C)
  • Intra-corneal ring segments (INTACS)- small curved PMMA ring or set of rings that are implanted in the cornea to help flatten corneal curvature to improve vision.
  • Corneal transplantation- Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) and penetrating keratoplasty (PKP)

Corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin (CXL or C3R) and ultraviolet-A rays arrest the progression of the disease. (Option D)

 

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

questions.text: A 40-year old male with progressive loss of vision in his left eye was diagnosed with against-the-rule astigmatism. Examination revealed peripheral corneal thinning, but there was no inflammation. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
The examination in a 40-year-old male revealed peripheral corneal thinning with no inflammation, making peripheral ulcerative keratitis, an inflammatory condition, the least likely cause.

Peripheral ulcerative keratitis is a destructive inflammatory disease involving the peripheral cornea. It is associated with signs and symptoms of inflammation. The other options are causes of peripheral thinning in a quiet eye. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Terrien's and Pellucid marginal degeneration are noninflammatory corneal degenerations. Pellucid degeneration causes bilateral, inferior corneal thinning that leads to marked, irregular, against-the-rule astigmatism. Terrien's degeneration usually begins in the superior cornea. 

Option C: Dellen is a localized thinning of the peripheral cornea associated with the drying of a focal area. Usually associated with an adjacent elevated lesion (e.g., pinguecula or a large subconjunctival haemorrhage) that impairs physiological lubrication.

Deposition of immune complexes in the terminal ends of limbal vessels initiates immune-mediated vasculitis, and causes inflammatory cell and protein leakage due to vessel wall damage. Development of peripheral ulcerative keratitis associated with systemic disease may represent worsening of a potentially life-threatening disease.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presented with tearing, irritation, and photophobia of the left eye. On examination, a paracentral, crescent-shaped corneal melt was noted. Peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK) was suspected. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is commonly associated with peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK). It is also the most common cause. 

PUK is a group of destructive inflammatory diseases involving the peripheral cornea, characterized by the sloughing of corneal epithelium and keratolysis (corneal melting). It can lead to corneal perforation. The causes can be divided into:

  • Infectious- bacterial, viral, protozoal, fungal.
  • Non-infectious- rheumatoid arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis, SLE, rosacea, psoriasis etc.

Ophthalmologic manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis (due to type III and IV hypersensitivity reactions):

  • dry eye
  • scleritis
  • stromal keratitis
  • peripheral ulcerative keratitis
  • paracentral keratolysis

Treatment of PUK includes protection of the surface from drying and exposure; systemic corticosteroids and immunomodulatory; use of adjuncts such as amniotic membrane grafts to promote healing; and in some situations, tectonic keratoplasty.

questions.text: A 54-year-old school teacher presented with a chief complaint of pain in the eyes and intermittent blurry vision which was worse in the mornings. Generalized corneal haze was noted in both eyes but was more significant in the left. Examination findings are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with beaten metal appearance on slit lamp and reduced endothelial cell density with coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, slowly progressive, often asymmetric corneal disease. It is characterized by deterioration of endothelial cells and development of guttata, which are excrescences of Descemet’s membrane (seen on specular or confocal microscopy). Females are affected more than males. It is more common in the 4th decade or later. 

Endothelial layer dysfunction causes loss of corneal deturgescence, and bilateral oedema of the stroma, leading to ocular pain, glare, halos, and decreased visual acuity. Patients have a worse vision in the morning because of the eyes being closed during the night causing a buildup of corneal oedema.

Stages of Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy:

  • Stage 1: Central corneal guttata that spreads peripherally
  • Stage 2: Corneal oedema - beaten metal-like appearance 
  • Stage 3: Bullous keratopathy
  • Stage 4: Subepithelial scarring and superficial vascularization

Treatment:

  • Conservative option- topical hypertonic (saline sodium chloride 5% drops or 6% ointment) and bandage contact lenses.
  • The definitive treatment is endothelial keratoplasty: Descemet’s stripping endothelial keratoplasty (DSEK/DSAEK) or Descemet membrane Endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK).

 

Related Pearl: Types of Corneal Dystrophies

Epithelial

  • Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD)
  • Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy
  • Meesman’s dystrophy
  • Lisch’s epithelial dystrophy
  • Gelatinous drop-like dystrophy

Bowman’s Membrane

  • Reis Buckler’s dystrophy
  • Thiel-Behnke corneal dystrophy
  • Grayson-Wilbrandt corneal dystrophy

Stromal Corneal Dystrophies

  • Granular dystrophy
  • Macular corneal dystrophy
  • Schnyder corneal dystrophy
  • Fleck corneal dystrophy
  • Posterior amorphous corneal dystrophy

  • Posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy (PPCD)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about macular corneal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Macular dystrophy does not spare the peripheral cornea. 

It is the least common corneal dystrophy. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance. Most other corneal dystrophies are autosomal dominant. It is associated with mucopolysaccharidoses and is characterized by the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the stroma and staining by Alcian blue. It develops in childhood and is progressive, resulting in profound visual impairment in early adult life.

Clinical examination reveals superficial whitish fleck-like opacities. These opacities extend peripherally to the limbus and the deep stroma down to Descemet’s membrane. The intervening corneal stroma develops a progressive and diffuse haze. 

Note:

  • Most common dystrophy overall- Microcystic/fingerprint/map-dot dystrophy
  • Most common stromal dystrophy- Lattice dystrophy
  • Dystrophy with corectopia- Posterior polymorphous dystrophy
  • Autosomal recessive dystrophy- Macular dystrophy

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used in identifying granular dystrophy of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Masson trichrome stains stromal hyaline deposits in granular dystrophy of the cornea.

Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene.

Granular corneal dystrophy is characterized by milky, granular, hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma, which may coalesce into irregular shapes. The peripheral cornea and the area between the opacities/deposits remain clear. Early symptoms may involve light sensitivity, glare, ocular discomfort, pain, and watering. As opacification progresses with age, visual acuity decreases.

The following image shows numerous irregularly shaped discrete crumb-like corneal opacities of Granular dystrophy, which stain bright red with Masson trichrome.

Related Pearl: Types of Corneal Dystrophies

Epithelial

  • Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD)
  • Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of oil-droplet keratopathy?

choices.text: Deposition of lipid in the anterior stroma

questions.solution:
Oil-droplet keratopathy occurs due to exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays. 

Climatic droplet keratopathy (CDK), alternatively known as oil droplet keratopathy/spheroidal degeneration/Labrador keratopathy, is an acquired corneal degenerative disorder. Clumps of variably sized golden-yellow globules accumulate in the superficial corneal stroma and are thought to be derived from photochemical degradation of plasma proteins, by UV radiation. 

The image shows Labrador keratopathy.

Other options: 

Option A: Lipid keratopathy involves the accumulation of whitish or yellow fat deposits, mainly cholesterol and fatty acids, which begin intracellularly and later move extracellularly due to necrosis of corneal stromal cells. It can be primary (rare, in the cornea free of vascularization) or secondary (common, in the vascularized cornea).

Option C: Exposure keratopathy results from lagophthalmos (incomplete eyelid closure), causing corneal dryness despite normal tear production. Causes include neuroparalytic conditions (like facial nerve palsy), reduced muscle tone in Parkinsonism, lid scarring, post-blepharoplasty and proptosis. 

Option D: Neurotrophic keratopathy results from loss of trigeminal nerve innervation to the cornea, affecting both sensation and healing. This disruption can cause corneal dryness, ulceration, exfoliation, and edema. It is commonly linked to conditions such as trigeminal ganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia, stroke, diabetes, herpes simplex and herpes zoster keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation is false?

choices.text: It is used in the management of keratoconus.
Corneal perforation is a very common complication.
It is made of polymethyl methacrylate.

questions.solution:
Corneal perforation may occur but is quite rare in intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation.

Salient points on ICRS:

  • These segments are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and are implanted into the mid-peripheral corneal stroma.
  • These are used in the management of keratoconus and low myopia.
  • Improvement in visual acuity and refraction after ICRS implantation is accomplished by a shortening of collagen lamellae along the arc length of the ring. There is a redistribution of corneal stress due to a change in the curvature of the cornea after implantation of the ICRS.
  • Decreased corneal sensation can be a postoperative complication.
  • More than 90% of patients have <1 D change in refraction at 1-year postoperative follow-up.

 The image shows the intrastromal corneal ring segment.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with normal visual acuity undergoes a routine eye exam. Slit-lamp examination reveals numerous crumb-like centrally dense deposits in the anterior corneal stroma, bilaterally symmetrical, with clear intervening stroma. Which of the following statements is likely to be true?

choices.text: Histopathology specimen will stain positive with alcian blue
Histopathologic review will reveal amyloid deposits on congo red staining
Histopathologic review will reveal hyaline deposits on the Masson trichrome stain

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with the given image showing multiple breadcrumb-like deposits, is suggestive of granular corneal dystrophy, where histopathology reveals hyaline deposits on the Masson trichrome stain.

Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene.

In granular corneal dystrophy, opacities form due to the abnormal accumulation of hyaline protein, assuming a discrete granular form and subsequently coalescing into various irregular shapes. The cornea between the opacities and the peripheral cornea remains clear. The condition is characterised by milky granular hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma.

In many patients, no symptoms occur, whereas some patients develop recurrent erosions. In the fifth decade or later, some patients develop sufficient visual difficulties to require keratoplasty. Treatment is usually keratoplasty for severe visual handicaps.

Note: The beaten metal appearance on the slit lamp and reduced endothelial cell density with coalescing guttata on specular microscopy is suggestive of Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought with a history of diffuse, ground glass-like corneal haze in both eyes. The corneas are thickened with normal diameters and associated nystagmus. Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Intraocular pressure (IOP) is likely to be elevated.
The corneal stroma shows abnormal deposits that stain with amyloid.
It could be a bilateral choristoma.
Descemet’s membrane may be thickened due to an abnormal endothelium.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario most likely suggest congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED), where Descemet’s membrane is abnormally thickened. 

CHED is a rare disorder characterized by focal or diffuse thickening of the Descemet membrane and endothelial degeneration. The key features of this condition include corneal thickness, which is two to three times the normal, normal intraocular pressure (IOP) and normal corneal diameter. Associated features are corneal pannus, nystagmus, and esotropia.

Treatment usually involves corneal transplantation (lamellar or penetrating keratoplasty) for visual rehabilitation.

Other options:

Option A: As the corneal diameters are normal, and there are no typical symptoms, congenital glaucoma is ruled out.

Option B: Amyloid deposits in the corneal stroma are seen in Lattice stromal dystrophy.

Option C: Choristomas are congenital lesions representing normal tissue(s) in an abnormal location. They are the most common epibulbar and orbital tumors in children. It usually arises at the limbus of the eye and may include dermoid tissue, lipodermoid or other tissues.

Note: The combination of congenital endothelial dystrophy and progressive neural deafness, is known as Harboyan syndrome. This disorder must be distinguished from another autosomal recessive disorder, congenital endothelial dystrophy, in which deafness does not occur.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Mooren's ulcer?

choices.text: Painless superficial ulcer that can perforate
Associated with autoimmune and rheumatological conditions
Characterized by a steep, overhanging edge
Ulcerative process begins centrally and then moves circumferentially

questions.solution:
Moorens’s ulcer/ulcus roden is characterized by a steep, overhanging edge.

It is described as a chronic serpiginous ulcer of the cornea. It is a subtype of peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK). It is defined as an idiopathic condition without associated systemic or rheumatological conditions and hence is a diagnosis of exclusion. The pathophysiology is thought to be due to autoimmune.

Clinical features include redness, tearing, and photophobia, but pain is typically the outstanding feature. The pain often is incapacitating and may well be out of proportion to the inflammation. There may also be a complaint of decreased visual acuity, which may be secondary to associated iritis or central corneal involvement. 

Initially, the ulcerative process spreads circumferentially. Later, it moves centrally to involve the entire cornea. In contrast to other forms of PUK, the limbus is involved. The end-stage result is typically a scarred, vascularized cornea that may be thinned to less than half of its original thickness. 

Treatment involves corticosteroids and excision of a strip of adjacent conjunctiva, which eliminates the conjunctival sources of collagenase and proteoglycanase.  

The image shows a perforated Mooren's ulcer.

questions.text: Which layer of the cornea is affected in Reis–Buckler dystrophy?
questions.solution:
The corneal layer involved in Reis–Buckler dystrophy is Bowman’s membrane.

Corneal dystrophies are primarily a bilateral, inherited, non-inflammatory condition specific to the cornea.

Reis–Buckler dystrophy, an autosomal dominant disorder, is an anterior variant of granular stromal dystrophy, characterised by the replacement of the Bowman layer with connective tissue bands, primarily affecting the Bowman layer and superficial stroma. Several recurrent corneal erosions may occur in childhood along with visual impairment. 

In this condition, there are grey-white, geographic subepithelial opacities (that are most dense centrally and increase over time, eventually forming a reticular pattern. Additionally, corneal sensation is reduced as the disease progresses.
